models.conversations: A chat session between a user and the platform, containing a sequence of messages. Can be starred for quick access later.
models.messages: A single exchange within a conversation â€” either a user question or an assistant response. Assistant messages can include generative UI cards.
models.zoneInfoCard: A card displaying zoning district details including permitted uses, dimensional standards, and code references.
models.parcelAnalysisCard: A feasibility assessment card showing whether a proposed use is permitted, conditional, or prohibited on a specific parcel.
models.incentivesSummaryCard: A card summarizing available financial incentives like TIF districts, Opportunity Zones, and BIDs for a location.
models.areaPlanContextCard: A card explaining how a project aligns with the neighborhood's adopted area plan and community goals.
models.permitProcessCard: A timeline card showing the steps, documents, fees, and contacts needed to get project approval.
models.codeCitationCard: A card with a direct quote from the zoning code or other official document, with source reference.
models.opportunityListCard: A card listing available properties that match a user's search criteria with match scores.

relationships: Each Conversation contains multiple Messages in sequence
Messages can include one or more generative UI cards as attachments
Cards reference Parcels, ZoningDistricts, IncentiveZones, and AreaPlans from the data model

conversations.preview: Can I build an ADU for my mother in my backyard?

messages.content: Can I build an ADU for my mother in my backyard at 3847 N 40th Street?
Great question! I've looked up your property at 3847 N 40th Street in the Sherman Park neighborhood. Here's what I found about building an Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU):

data.description: Low-density residential district permitting single-family homes and accessory structures.

requirements: ADU must not exceed 800 sq ft or 50% of primary dwelling
Owner must occupy either primary or ADU
nextSteps: Provide site plan showing ADU location

messages.content: Are there any grants or incentives I could use to help pay for this?
Yes! Your property is in an area with several potential funding sources. Here's what's available:

incentives.name: STRONG Homes Loan Program
incentives.description: City program offering 0-3% interest loans for home improvements including ADUs in targeted neighborhoods.

incentives.name: Sherman Park NID Grant
incentives.description: Neighborhood Improvement District matching grant for exterior improvements and additions.

incentives.name: Opportunity Zone
incentives.description: Federal tax benefits for qualified investments, primarily for larger projects.

data.recommendation: The STRONG Homes Loan combined with the Sherman Park NID Grant could cover a significant portion of your ADU construction costs.

communityGoals: Preserve neighborhood character while allowing gentle density
Encourage investment in existing housing stock
relevantRecommendations: Encourage ADUs as a means to provide affordable housing and support aging in place
Maintain consistent setbacks and building heights with surrounding homes

steps.name: Pre-Application Meeting
steps.description: Optional but recommended meeting with DNS staff to review project scope

steps.name: Building Permit Application
steps.description: Submit application with site plan, floor plans, and specifications

steps.name: Plan Review
steps.description: City reviews plans for code compliance

steps.name: Permit Issuance
steps.description: Once approved, permit is issued and construction can begin

steps.name: Inspections & Certificate of Occupancy
steps.description: Inspections during construction, final CO issued upon completion

data.title: Accessory Dwelling Units
data.excerpt: An accessory dwelling unit shall be permitted in all single-family residential districts subject to the following standards: (a) The floor area of an ADU shall not exceed 800 square feet or 50% of the floor area of the principal dwelling, whichever is less. (b) The property owner shall occupy either the principal dwelling or the ADU as their primary residence.
data.sourceDocument: Milwaukee Code of Ordinances, Chapter 295 - Zoning
data.relevance: This section establishes the size limits and owner-occupancy requirements for your proposed ADU.

data.searchCriteria: TIF-eligible vacant lots, 5000-15000 sq ft, Bronzeville
